titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Philip Kapleau papers, 1952-2009 and undated RL.11661
titlestmt.author: Laurin Penland

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-07-08 14:00:49 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Zen Buddhist teacher and author of "The Three Pillars of Zen." Born in New Haven, Connecticut, Kapleau was a chief court reporter for the Nuremberg Trials and also covered the Tokyo War Crimes Trials. While in Japan for the trials, he met and was influenced by D.T. Suzuki and other Zen practitioners, which led him to become a serious student of Zen in Japan. Eventually, he returned to the United States and founded the Rochester Zen Center (New York) in 1966. Most of the papers relate to Kapleau's role as a Zen teacher, to his writings, and to personal concerns such as his health and Parkinson's disease. Some of Kapleau's notes are written in shorthand, and there are some materials in Japanese. The recorded teishos (dharma talks) were mainly recorded during sesshin (retreats) and span 30 years. According to the tape labels, there are various speakers including Kapleau, Toni Packer, and Bodhin Kjolhede (all of whom led the Rochester Zen Center at different times).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into three series: Correspondence, Subject Files, and Recorded Teishos (Dharma talks). Original file names were maintained when possible.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Zen Buddhist teacher and author of several books, including "The Three Pillars of Zen." Born in New Haven, Connecticut, Kapleau was a chief court reporter for the Nuremberg Trials, and he also covered the Tokyo War Crimes Trials. While in Japan for the trials, he met and was influenced by D.T. Suzuki and other Zen practitioners. He returned to the United States and attended classes taught by D.T. Suzuki at Columbia University. He then decided to go back to Japan and to become a serious student of Zen. He stayed in Japan for 13 years and studied with Zen Master Hakuun Yasutani and others. Eventually, he returned to the United States and founded the Rochester Zen Center (New York) in 1966. He is credited with spreading Zen Buddhism to Westerners through his writings and teachings.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Philip Kapleau Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018 and 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], The Philip Kapleau Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Laurin Penland and Kamilla Pinter, November 2018. Revised by Laurin Penland, March 2019.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0019, 2019-0018, 2019-0071.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Papers related to Kapleau's role as a Zen teacher, to his writings, and to his personal concerns such as his health and Parkinson's disease. He corresponded with students and Zen practitioners all over the world and kept copies of his responses. There are a few notable letters from the 1950s, one from D.T. Suzuki and one from Hakuun Yasutani (written to Kapleau's sister Jean Kapleau). Many of the letters are from people who learned about Kapleau by reading his book, "The Three Pillars of Zen." Other letters pertain to the Rochester Zen Center (New York) and many other Zen centers. The subject files contain articles (many that are written by others), clippings, newsletters, and notes related to politics, animal rights, religion, environmentalism, Zen workshops, psychotherapy, travel, and health and diet. Some of Kapleau's notes are written in shorthand and there are some materials in Japanese. The recorded teishos (dharma talks) were mainly recorded during sesshin (retreats). According to the tape labels, there are various speakers including Kapleau, Toni Packer, and Bodhin Kjolhede (all of whom led the Rochester Zen Center at different times).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Contact Research Services in advance to request the production of listening or viewing copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes materials related to writing a biography about Philip Kapleau, including correspondence from Polly Young-Eisendrath, articles, and interviews.
